PHRASE.Comment: This is the only entry for this key.
The names of the months in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Month 2008'.

The names of the week in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Week, Month Date, Year'. These are the civil weeks for use with the Greogorian Calendar (An issue for the Chinese version).
The names of the months in the genitive case, that is, for use in the format 'Wednesday, 28 March 2008'.

The names of the months in the genitive case, that is, for use in the format 'Wednesday, 28 March 2008'. These are the civil months that are to be used for the Greogorian calendar (An issue for the Chinese version).

The names of the week in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Week, Month Date, Year'. These are the civil weeks for use with the Greogorian Calendar (An issue for the Chinese version).

PHRASE.Value: WW, DD MM YY
PHRASE.Comment: This will display a type similar to Wednesday, 28 August 2008. The permissible codes are WW for Weekname, DD for the day number, MM for the month, YY for the year. Any additonal formatting can be included such as comma after any number.

PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying all the relevant information on screen for the Main interface. A blank entry of "" will select the default font.
The size of the font for the Main interface, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 14.

PHRASE.Value: Times New Roman
PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying information in the Liturgical aspect. At times, the font of the Liturgics will be different from that of the main Screen (for example, Russian interface; Church Slavonic Liturgics).
The size of the font for the Liturgics aspect (see FontFaceL) for explanation, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 14.
This is the mark to separate the different commemorations that are dispalyed. Spaces on both sides, if required, must be included. This is to avoid issues with East Asian languages.
This is the mark to separate the readings. Spaces on both sides, if required, must be included. This is to avoid issues with East Asian languages.
This is for everytime that a colon is required. Spaces on both sides, if required, must be included. This is to avoid issues with East Asian languages.

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given language. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0. The true 'Arabic' numerals have a zero point at '٠' (\u0660).
This allows ideographic numerals to be displayed instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be displayed as for example, CXLV.
This gives the format for the time. The 24-hour clock will be used.
Ceci est la seule valeur pour cette clé.

PHRASE.Value: janvier/,février/,mars/,avril/,mai/,juin/,juillet/,août/,septembre/,octobre/,novembre/,décembre
PHRASE.Comment: Les noms des mois dans le cas nominatif, utilisés dans la forme 'mois année'.
Les noms de la semaine dans le cas nominatif, utilisés dans la forme 'semaine, mois numéro, année'.

PHRASE.Value: janvier/,février/,mars/,avril/,mai/,juin/,juillet/,août/,septembre/,octobre/,novembre/,décembre
PHRASE.Comment: Les noms des mois dans le cas génitif, utilisés dans la forme 'jour, le numéro mois année'.
Les noms de la semaine dans le cas nominatif, utilisés dans la forme 'semaine, mois numéro, année'.

PHRASE.Value: janvier/,février/,mars/,avril/,mai/,juin/,juillet/,août/,septembre/,octobre/,novembre/,décembre
PHRASE.Comment: Les noms des mois dans le cas génitif, utilisés dans la forme 'jour, le numéro mois année'.

Version/,Ponomar est désigné enfin que l'utilisateur peut comprendre et connaître la richesse et la beauté de la tradition Orthodoxe. Le programme est dans sa phase développementale./,Chez Ponomar, nous croyons que les textes Orthodoxes doivent être libre pour les utiliser et les distribuer. Dieu n'avait pas réclamé ses droits d’auteur sur le Bible. St. Jean Damascène n'avait pas réclamé ses droits d’auteur sur l'Octoèques. Donc, Ponomar et tous les textes, qui sont incorporés dans Ponomar, sont distribués sur les termes de GPL./,Droits d’Auteur réservés/,par/,Reconnaissances : (Aucuns)
Jordanville/,Saute Lucienne/,Le lectionnaire d'Évangile/,Sélectionner le lectionnaire d'Évangile désirée.

PHRASE.Comment: Ceci sont les formes placée dans les parenthèses après les lectures transférées (l'Évangile et l'Épître).

PHRASE.Value: WW, le DD MM YY
PHRASE.Comment: Ceci montrera quelque chose similaire à mercredi, le 28 août 2008. Les clés permis sont WW pour le jour, DD for numéro de jour, MM pour le mois, YY pour l'année. Des informations supplémentaires, comme une comma, pourraient inclus.

PHRASE.Value: Times New Roman
PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying information in the Liturgical aspect. At times, the font of the Liturgics will be different from that of the main Screen (for example, Russian interface; Church Slavonic Liturgics).

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given language. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0!
This allows ideographic numerals to be displayed instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be displayed as for example, CXLV.

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given language. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0!
This allows ideographic numerals to be displayed instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be displayed as for example, CXLV.
This gives the format for the time. The 24-hour clock will be used.

PHRASE.Comment: This is the only entry for this key.

Hirmos Ponomar
PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying all the relevant information on screen for the Main interface. A blank entry of "" will select the default font.
The size of the font for the Main interface, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 12.

PHRASE.Value: Hirmos Ponomar
PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying information in the Liturgical aspect. At times, the font of the Liturgics will be different from that of the main Screen (for example, Russian interface; Church Slavonic Liturgics).
The size of the font for the Liturgics aspect (see FontFaceL) for explanation, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 12.
This is the mark to separate the different commemorations that are dispalyed.
This is the mark to separate the readings.
This is for everytime that a colon is required.

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given language. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0!
This allows ideographic numerals to be displayed instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be displayed as for example, CXLV. 1 = yes!

PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying all the relevant information on screen for the Main interface. A blank entry of "" will select the default font.
The size of the font for the Main interface, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 12.

This is the font to be used for displaying information in the Liturgical aspect. At times, the font of the Liturgics will be different from that of the main Screen (for example, Russian interface; Church Slavonic Liturgics).
The size of the font for the Liturgics aspect (see FontFaceL) for explanation, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 12.
This is the mark to separate the different commemorations that are dispalyed.
This is the mark to separate the readings.
This is for everytime that a colon is required.

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given language. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0!
This allows ideographic numerals to be displayed instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be displayed as for example, CXLV. 1 = yes!

PHRASE.Value: HH時MM分
PHRASE.Comment: This gives the format for the time. The 24-hour clock will be used.

DONE.Value: MenuFiles, LanguagePack, LanguageSelector, About, ConfigurationFiles, Main, GospelSelector, OrderedHashtable, DocHanlder,QDParser, Sunrise, JCalendar, JDaySelector, Paschalion, Primes, DivineLiturgy, StringOp (I could not successfully translate this section),JDate,Bible,
